Award.AwardTitle: Managing the Honor and Stigma of Disjunctive Identities

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research supported by this award investigates social groups that have highly disjunctive identities. Disjunctive identities are two or more shared forms of identity that are ranked very differently. The researcher asks how these groups and the people in them manage how they see themselves and the social status assigned to them, and how outsiders respond to those management efforts. Such groups often wish to present their more highly ranked identity as a visible public face, yet they may simultaneously wish to preserve the traditions and values of their other, less esteemed identity. While a wide range of research has explored the experiences of individuals, families, or even larger subsets of groups with disjunctive identities, almost no research has been carried out among entire groups who consciously and intentionally bear one identity considered high status and the other considered much lower. This research will help policy-makers, practitioners, and social scientists understand how social groups live with and manage disjunctive identities, as well as provide models for how such groups may promote their own interests.

This research will take place in Madurai, South India, where the researcher, anthropologist Dr. Sara Dickey of Bowdoin College, has carried out ethnographic fieldwork since 1985. She has chosen to focus on the case of the Hindu Nadars, because they have historically occupied one of the lowest ranks in the caste system but today also form one of the wealthiest groups in the region, well-known for public philanthropy such as building hospitals and schools. The researcher will focus on the role of Nadar community organizations, which, for more than a century, have actively tried to control the types of Nadar behaviors and values that are made visible to the larger public and the debates about values and identities that occur within these organizations. The researcher will gather data with a mix of ethnographic methods, including participant observation, the collection of oral histories, interviews, and archival research. Findings from the research will elucidate the extent to which economic success and cultural sophistication can mitigate social discrimination, and how recent developments, such as economic globalization, have affected this process. Results may provide models for U.S. settings and may suggest new approaches to help under-represented students manage disparate identities and thereby enhance academic and social success.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Working with members of the Hindu Nadar caste community in urban South India, this project explores how social groups negotiate private and public identities when they occupy highly disjunctive statuses, that is, statuses perceived to carry distinctly different levels of honor and stigma. Historically viewed as one of the lowest-ranked castes, Nadars have also become one of the wealthiest communities in the region in the past century. We know little about what it is like for an entire self-identified community to live with two disjunctive identities that are publicly visible, nor how outsiders? classifications of the group shape interactions with and within the community. Both processes ? self-construction of identity and interactions between groups ? are central determinants of social structures and inequalities.

 

To understand how Hindu Nadars negotiate and navigate their social identities, this project focusses on a range of civic, organizational, religious, and discursive activities. Research methods included semi-structured interviews with Hindu Nadars, Christian Nadars, and outsiders; observation of Hindu Nadar rituals, including annual temple festivals, daily worship, and life-cycle rituals (primarily weddings and puberty rituals); attendance at caste association meetings; and visits to civic projects such as Nadar-sponsored schools and hospitals. Interviews were carried out with people of varying ages, occupations, educational levels, classes, ritual roles, genders, ?native places,? and lineages.

 

Nadars? contemporary social and economic standings (including their forms of economic, cultural, and social capital) demonstrate that, to a significant extent, the impacts of a low caste ranking can be mitigated by achieving a relatively higher class ranking. On the other hand, the continuing negative stereotypes held of Nadars ? which, while generally voiced covertly, are akin to discriminatory ethnic, religious, and racial slurs in the U.S. ? are one of the forms of evidence that class cannot entirely overcome caste prejudice in India, despite pronouncements to the contrary. Awareness of such continuing prejudice creates a diffuse sense of unease among many Hindu Nadars about their social place in the city and their acceptance by higher castes.

 

Nadar individuals, families, and organizations aim to reconcile these continuing disjunctions in varied and sometimes conflicting ways. Caste associations frequently support civic projects that are widely viewed as contributions to the urban public, and their work is supported by most Nadars (financially and otherwise), aiming to create positive regard for the community. Some Nadars adapt caste-specific religious practices and life-cycle rituals to fit more closely with higher caste forms of Hindu worship (de-emphasizing possession during temple festivals, for example, and employing Brahman priests in temples and in major family rituals). Other Nadar families, however, overtly reject such influences, maintaining lineal traditions of fierce god possession, and carrying out ?self-respect? weddings without priests. Nadars can be as critical of one another?s forms of worship as higher castes can be of Nadars? religiosity as a whole, revealing divisions within the community.

 

Many discursive practices also reveal such tensions. When recounting the history of the Nadar community, for example, some Madurai Nadars represent themselves as descendants of ancient rulers and warriors, arguing that their current success is simply a reclaiming of their rightful standing. Others emphasize inherent Nadar traits of hard work and trustworthiness that, over the past two centures, have allowed them to overcome oppression that different castes were unable to escape. Still others take an entirely different approach to the relationship between caste stigma and class honor, arguing that because Nadars were historically provided advantages not available to other similarly ranked castes (e.g., access to colonial missionary schooling), they should use their wealth, education, and political acumen privileges to address the disadvantages faced by the lowest-ranked castes today, and thus challenge the caste system as a whole.

 

All of these diverse efforts ultimately raise the question of how Nadars and others assess contemporary ?status? in an urban community. While caste and class are often identified as entirely distinguishable forms of ranking, there is significant evidence that a person?s, family?s, or caste community?s overall standing is most often determined by themselves and others through a melded amalgamation of ranked forms of identity, rather than separately by caste and by class categories. Exploring such questions continues to document the intricate relationships between class and caste ? institutions that work together to create a significant impact on access to resources, the construction of identities, and the quality of daily life.

 

These data and findings enable a more realistic understanding of the challenges faced by those with such disjunctive identities; of the strategies available for self-presentation; and of the ways in which distinct identities can be merged to form a sense of self or an integrated communal identity. Nadars? social experiences advance our understanding of complex social identities, social relations, the inequalities that these help to produce, and the means by which such inequalities may be redressed.
